articles.headline: Vote on Boehner Plan Delayed Amid Opposition
articles.snippet: House Republican leaders said they planned to delay a scheduled vote on a plan to temporarily raise the debt ceiling, as passage seemed in growing doubt.
articles.abstract: House Republican leaders said they planned to delay a scheduled vote on a plan to temporarily raise the debt ceiling, as passage seemed in growing doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders were forced on Tuesday night to delay a vote scheduled on their plan to raise the nation’s debt ceiling, as conservative lawmakers expressed skepticism and Congressional budget officials said the plan did not deliver the promised savings.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Billionaires’ Rise Aids India, and the Favor Is Returned
articles.snippet: India’s new billionaires attest to the private sector’s growth in areas once controlled by the state such as telecommunications, ports, airports, banks and infrastructure.
articles.abstract: India’s new billionaires attest to the private sector’s growth in areas once controlled by the state such as telecommunications, ports, airports, banks and infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNDRA, India — On a recent wind-whipped morning, a steel-hulled behemoth arrived at a desolate stretch of India’s western coast groaning with enough coal to power a city of one million people for more than two weeks.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: In Ford’s and Chrysler’s Earnings, Auto Industry Comeback Shows Slowdown
articles.snippet: Two of Detroit’s Big Three, Ford and Chrysler, reported tepid second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, providing more evidence that the industry revival had slowed to a crawl.
articles.abstract: Two of Detroit’s Big Three, Ford and Chrysler, reported tepid second-quarter earnings on Tuesday, providing more evidence that the industry revival had slowed to a crawl.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Just when the American auto industry appeared ready to hit a higher gear, its comeback has shifted into neutral.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: McDonald’s Trims Its Happy Meal
articles.snippet: Bowing to pressure from health advocates and parents, McDonald’s will try to cut the calorie count of the Happy Meal by reducing the portion of French fries and adding fruit.
articles.abstract: Bowing to pressure from health advocates and parents, McDonald’s will try to cut the calorie count of the Happy Meal by reducing the portion of French fries and adding fruit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bowing to pressure from health advocates and parents, McDonald’s is putting the Happy Meal on a diet.

articles.headline: How a Debt Downgrade May Affect Consumers
articles.snippet: If the nation’s credit rating is downgraded because of the debt standoff , investors and borrowers should be able to ride out any resulting volatility, experts said.
articles.abstract: If the nation’s credit rating is downgraded because of the debt standoff , investors and borrowers should be able to ride out any resulting volatility, experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is not yet one of those stuff-your-money-in-a-mattress moments.

articles.headline: On All Levels of the Economy, Concern About the Impasse
articles.snippet: If the United States’ credit rating drops because of a standoff over government spending, experts say borrowing costs, business confidence and job creation could all be affected.
articles.abstract: If the United States’ credit rating drops because of a standoff over government spending, experts say borrowing costs, business confidence and job creation could all be affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economists and analysts are trying to gauge the costs to the economy and consumers if the United States loses its solid-gold credit rating — a move that appears more likely now that the standoff in Washington over government spending has calcified.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Louise Story

articles.headline: Lessons From the Malaise
articles.snippet: Nuances and caveats help to keep the nation from solving some straightforward questions about the economy.
articles.abstract: Nuances and caveats help to keep the nation from solving some straightforward questions about the economy.

articles.headline: Affluent Buyers Reviving Market for Miami Homes
articles.snippet: In a market that many expected to be depressed for a decade, there are plans of building even more high-rise condominiums.
articles.abstract: In a market that many expected to be depressed for a decade, there are plans of building even more high-rise condominiums.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — South Florida is the default capital of the country. Here in Miami-Dade County, one out of five households with mortgages is in foreclosure. Nearby Broward and Palm Beach counties are not far behind. Nearly 200,000 South Florida families are stuck in the mire of default.

articles.headline: Among Twists in Budget Woes, Tensions Over Teaching the Deaf
articles.snippet: The appointments of new board members for the Indiana School for the Deaf has reignited a debate over how deaf people should be educated.
articles.abstract: The appointments of new board members for the Indiana School for the Deaf has reignited a debate over how deaf people should be educated.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Politicians have seen plenty of demonstrators outside the Statehouse here. But the crowd that gathered last month was a bit different from the usual shouting protesters.

articles.headline: In Both Houses, Fortifying Support for Rival Plans
articles.snippet: House Republicans and Senate Democrats gained support within party ranks for their separate plans to resolve a debt crisis, but the momentum seemed to be pushing both sides further from a compromise.
articles.abstract: House Republicans and Senate Democrats gained support within party ranks for their separate plans to resolve a debt crisis, but the momentum seemed to be pushing both sides further from a compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans and Senate Democrats gained substantial support on Wednesday within party ranks for their separate plans to resolve a looming debt crisis, but the momentum seemed to be pushing both sides further from a compromise.
